results.title: Five Aboriginal dances from Cape York
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The legends and stories of Australia’s First Nations peoples have been kept alive in song and dance. This film shows dancing at the Aurunum Mission Station in the north of Queensland. The dances are: “ATHA AND PANTJ” - three men die and change into the crow, dove and gecko lizard; “MUIPAKA” - the penalty for adultery is death; “NINGKUSHUN AND ORPUL” - Orpul the fairy girl created the freshwater shark; “PIKUWA AND KENA” - the freshwater and saltwater crocodile fight; “PIPAPEPE” - the courting and mating of the curlews.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Australian Aborigines: everything from nature
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Our reliance on manufactured goods is contrasted with the First Nations peoples’ ability to use the natural materials around them, which gives rise to a marked respect for their adaptability and sensitivity to the land. Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land.

results.title: The Esperance story
results.creator_credit: Michael Thornhill, Richard Mason, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Western Australia. Dept. of Native Welfare
results.brief_description: Esperance, a small town on the southern coast of Western Australia, is a community centre for wealthy pastoralists and graziers. A smaller number of First Nations people also live thereunder the control of the Western Australian Department of Native Welfare. The establishment of some First Nations farming businesses is an economic opportunity but also a challenge to the town’s culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Thornhill, Richard Mason, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Western Australia. Dept. of Native Welfare

results.title: Desert people
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Scenes typical of the daily life of the Pintubi tribe in the Western Desert cultural area, showing two families: the first was filmed as they were found living in desert conditions, the second had recently settled at Warburton Mission and demonstrated how they had lived a few months earlier. (A shorter version of People of the Australian Western Desert, Pts. l, 2 and 4.)

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for First Nations peoples in Australia to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work. Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.

results.title: Jardiwarnpa: a Warlpiri fire ceremony
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
In order to combat the influence of western culture the elders of the Warlpiri people, led by Darby Jampijinpa Ross, a noted Aboriginal artist, decided to perform a fire ceremony which tells the story of Yarripiri’s journey. Yarripiri is both a real person and an incarnation of a dreamtime spirit. This video documents the preparations for the ceremony, the ceremony itself, the story the ceremony recreates and the problems the people have in performing it. Narrated by Kev Carmody.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists

results.title: Broken English
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
In 1958, as a result of a forced confession, an inability to read or write English and the racial intolerance of the police and the community of the time, Rupert Max Stuart, an indigenous Australian man, was sentenced to hang for the rape and murder of a nine year old girl. Using dramatisation, archival film and interviews with those involved, including Stuart himself, this video charts the trial, appeals and subsequent attempts to overthrow the conviction.

results.title: The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger
results.creator_credit: Alan Lowery, ABC-TV (Australia) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description: A three part series in which John Pilger explores aspects of Australia’s history from first settlement, through its involvement in wars right through to today’s society, and looks at the plight of First Nations people throughout Australian history.
